Expectation1: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation1: A member of the community has scheduled an appointment to discuss a persistent personal struggle.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded hallway of the community center, my collar marking me as Father Michael to those who recognized me. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder that Mrs. Evans would be waiting in my office in less than an hour, hoping for comfort and guidance through her grief. I felt the weight of her trust, the expectation that I would be present, patient, and wise. But here I was, a voter, clutching my ID, inching forward in a line that snaked around the gym. Suddenly, an official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name, McCarthy, meant I was being asked to switch. The new line looked longer, slower, but the official’s voice was firm—this was the rule. I hesitated, torn. As a priest, I knew I couldn’t be late for Mrs. Evans; she needed me. As a citizen, I felt the pressure to comply, to set an example of following civic instructions. My heart pounded as I stood between two duties, feeling the pull of both, uncertain which to honor first.
